_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Fill alarm at 80% with auto. Shutoff at 85%, min. class 1 Div. 1 electric w/in 5 ft. of all transfer (truck offloading) points w/Class 1 Div. 2 from 5-15 feet, Class 1 Div. 2 w/in 15 ft. of remainder
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Hydrocarbon detectors, flow monitoring, temperature, pressure & liquid level indicators
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: System alarms, horns, hydrocarbon detectors, oxygen detector
_prev_prog_3.Description: Butane Blending System consists of one (1) vessel plus lines.  Butane (liquefied and stored under pressure), is blended via direct injection to refined product (gasoline) pipelines with bulk truck offloading.  System operations are anticipated to occur primarily during the cold season.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
s.  KMLT owns the real property associated with the Butane Blending System.  Sunoco Partners Butane Blending, LLC (Sunoco) owns all the equipment associated with the Butane Blending System.  Sunoco and KMLT each have operational responsibilities for the Butane Blending System.   Sunoco controls and monitors all butane blending operations remotely from its control center located near Houston, Texas, conducts all maintenance activities, and schedules the delivery of butane trucks.  KMLT oversees the unloading of butane trucks into both storage vessels and conducts routine visual inspections.



Sunoco constructed the Butane Blending System in accordance with the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA Code) No. 58 (2011 Edition) for Liquefied Petroleum Gas Storage.  Sunoco designed, constructed, and maintains the Butane Blending System, in accordance with NFPA No. 58 and the manufacturer's instructions and recommendations.



It is the Parties' policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws/codes.  If an emergency were to occur, it is the Parties' policy to notify the City of Bedford Park Fire Department as well as the Illinois Department of Emergency Management.  Medical emergencies will require notification of the local Emergency Management Services (911).



The Argo Butane Blending System's worst case scenario is the failure of the system's 60,000 gallon butane storage vessels which equates to 250,000 pounds of butane resulting in a vapor cloud explosion.  The system's alternate (potential off-site impact) release scenario is a "BLEVE" accident and associated fireball.



The Parties comply with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's EPA) Accident Prevention Rules (40 CFR Part 68 Subpart D), the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard and associated 14 elements (29 CFR Part 1910.119), and all applicable state and local laws and regulations.  This facility has not had an accident involv

ing butane which has resulted in deaths, injuries, property/environmental damage, evacuations or sheltering in place.



In the event of an emergency involving the Butane Blending System, it is the Parties' policy to initially contact the owner of the equipment - Sunoco and the local fire department.  The facility emergency response plans are coordinated with the local fire department.  The City of Bedford Park Fire Department personnel have participated in the initial RMP/PSM training session for this system.

Process safety controls include excess flow valves, low-melting point pneumatic valve feeds to pneumatic valves (fail closed), 85% fill shut-off (80% alarm and 90% ESD actuation) on the vessels, emergency shut-off devices on the system and video display terminal, line thermal/hydrostatic reliefs, and grounding interlock devices.  Additional vessel protection includes an intumescent coating.  Note: In contrast to the PSM requirements, this "stationary source" as defined under 40 CFR Part 68 is bounded by the off-load station and the points of injection. 



The Parties actively seek employee input on process safety improvements.  Additionally, the City of Bedford Park Fire Department is contacted regarding participation in site emergency response drills. Additional actions include consolidating separate system inspection checklists for ease of completion.

Facility Identification and Regulated Substances



The KMLT Argo Terminal is a public "for-hire" bulk liquid storage terminal, approximately 145 acres in area and located approximately 15 miles southwest of the Chicago, Illinois.  GATX Terminals Corporation owned and operated the Argo Terminal from 1951 until it was acquired by KMLT in March 2001.  The terminal is bounded by the Chicago Sanitary and Ship Canal to the west, Corn Products Corporation to the north, Archer Avenue to the east, and the Shell Oil Terminal and the Univar Distribution Facility to the south.  Bedford Park Fire Station Number 1 is loc

ated at the entrance to the Argo Terminal.  The terminal provides tank storage for liquid chemicals, petroleum, food grade products, and raw materials on a "contract" basis.  Presently approximately 215 permitted aboveground storage tanks are available (approximately 111,000,000 gallon capacity) for storage and distribution of customer products or for support activities.  Materials are received at the terminal by tank trucks, rail cars, barge, and pipeline.   



Of the permitted aboveground storage tanks, one tank, Tank 5-15 (for storage of vinyl acetate) is covered by the RMP regulation. Tank 5-15 has a total capacity of 215,000 gallons, but is restricted to a maximum working volume of 137,347 gallons to limit air emissions.



Policies to Protect Health, Safety and the Environment



Risk management and safety are important concerns at the Argo Terminal.  This RMP formalizes and documents these activities.  The facility is committed to conducting its operations in a safe and responsible manner and to reducing risks to human health and the environment. KMLT Argo Terminal reviews its safety and operating procedures annually to ensure accurate information is presented therein.



Prevention Program 



An Accidental Release Prevention Program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the EPA Risk Management Program requirements (40 CFR 68). This prevention program covers those processes that handle regulated substances above the threshold amount.  The prevention program provides a structured approach to preventing accidents. Some of the specific activities in the prevention program include:



- Keeping process safety information accessible at all times.

- Conducting a hazard review as part of the preparations for RMP compliance.

- Using written operating procedures to train and guide operators.

- Providing training to all employees that operate the system.

- Operating a program to properly maintain the system and equipme

nt.

- Investigating incidents and taking actions as part of a continuous improvement effort.

- Conducting routine audits to ensure that safe practices are followed.



Processes at the facility subject to the Risk Management Program are designed with extensive safeguards to protect against the accidental release of a hazardous material. Examples of safety equipment in place for the vinyl acetate storage include pressure relief devices, leak detection, and monitoring systems. For the Butane Blending process, process safety controls include excess flow valves, low melting point pneumatic valve feeds to pneumatic valves (fail safe), 85% fill shut-off, 90 % ESD actuation on the vessels, emergency shut-off devices on the system and video display terminal, line thermal/hydrostatic reliefs, and grounding interlock devices.    



In addition, process operators receive extensive training in the safe operation of the process and are required to follow detailed operating procedures to help ensure safety.  The facility also has implemented a maintenance program to monitor the physical condition of process equipment, and replace or repair equipment before it fails.



In the unlikely event of a spill or release involving a hazardous material, the Argo Terminal has developed an emergency response plan providing procedures to be followed to minimize the potential impacts of a fire at the facility. In the event of a release, the facility calls the Bedford Park Fire Department located at the facility boundary.



Hazard Evaluation



Under the EPA regulations, the facility is required to evaluate the potential consequences of a worst case release and various alternate release scenarios.  The following paragraphs provide a description of the worst case and alternate scenarios for the base. 



The RMP regulations define a worst-case release as "the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a vessel or process line failure that results in the greatest distance t

o an endpoint defined in Sections 68.22 (a)" (40 CFR 68.3). The worst-case release scenario for toxic liquids assumes that the total quantity in a vessel is spilled instantaneously onto a flat non-absorbing surface to form a pool.  Passive mitigation systems, such as dikes, are taken into account in the consequence analysis.  The release rate to air is estimated as the rate of evaporation from the pool of spilled toxic liquid.  Each tank at the Argo Terminal is located within a diked area. 



For Tank 5-15 (capacity 187,700 gallons), it is assumed that the contents of the tank empty instantaneously to a diked area.  The diked area is capable of holding the capacity of the largest tank, plus sufficient freeboard to allow for precipitation.  The evaporation rate is then determined using U.S. EPA's RMP*Comp program to determine the distance to the toxic endpoint. 



For the Butane Blending process, The "Worst-Case" scenario assumes a catastrophic system failure resulting in a total release of the flammable substance (Butane) from the single largest vessel (approximately 51,000 gallons [water capacity]) and the resulting vapor cloud explosion. The distance of the release and overpressure endpoint is determined by using U.S. EPA's RMP*Comp program.



Five-Year Accident History



For the 2015 RMP update, KMLT reported that no accidents had occurred during the previous five years. No accidents have occurred since the prior update was submitted.



Emergency Response Plan



The RMP regulations require that "response actions have been coordinated with local emergency planning and response agencies" (40 CFR 68.12(b)(3)).   Emergency response activities at the Argo Terminal are coordinated with the Cook County Central LEPC and Bedford Park Fire Department.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Safety and Emergency Preparedness is a part of the facility's activities.  Exposure risks to employees and the public have been minimized through ongoing inspections, maintenance,
and capital improvements.  Further improvements will continue to be implemented as appropriate.
